Write a short summary for the following passage:
The world number one and Olympic champion said his family was the most important thing in his life.
That realisation helped his tennis because it made him more resilient to setbacks on the court, he said.
Murray revealed he would have voted for triathlete Alistair Brownlee, who came second in the sports personality award.
Brownlee made headlines across the world when he selflessly helped his exhausted brother over the line at the end to the Triathlon World Series in Mexico.
In a interview with the BBC's John Inverdale, Murray said Brownlee's actions had sent out an important message.
"What they do in their career is obviously extremely tough, physical hard sport - but then at the end of something like that, it isn't just about the winning all of the time," he said.
"I think sometimes that gets lost a little bit in sport and I think that was a really important message.
"I have a brother who competes obviously at the highest level as well, so it was really nice to see that."
Murray received 247,419 votes in the award at the end of a year which saw him retain his Olympic title, win Wimbledon for a second time and become the first British player to top the world rankings since the current system was introduced in 1973.
He joined the awards ceremony by video link from Miami where he is training.
Murray was asked if he still had the same drive to succeed as he did six or seven years ago, before he had won a Grand Slam title.
He said: "I feel very different. I wouldn't say I want it more - and I think that's actually a positive thing.
"Before I used to stress myself out so much about tennis all the time. I would be really high when I won matches or tournaments and then I'd be really down when I didn't.
"Now as I've got older, obviously becoming a parent you realise that tennis is great, and sport - I love it, it's given me a lot - but family is the most important thing.
"And when I win tournaments it's really nice, it's a great feeling but I'm still looking forward to getting back to see my daughter and see my wife.
"When I lose I'm down obviously, but it's not just as drastic as it was before and I feel that's helped my tennis a lot. When I'm training and stuff I still love working hard. I still really enjoy that aspect of it but I'm not getting as much up and down based on how my results on the court go and I think that's really positive."
In his acceptance speech, Murray revealed his wife told him she voted for showjumper Nick Skelton -  who came third in the vote.
"I'm hoping she was joking," he said.
"I'll speak to her while I'm off air and find out definitely. It's my last day off before Christmas and I'm doing my Christmas shopping tonight. So if she gives me the wrong answer she's not getting anything."
Summary:
Murray revealed he would have voted for triathlete Alistair Brownlee, who came second in the sports personality award.
Brownlee made headlines across the world when he selflessly helped his exhausted brother over the line at the end to the Triathlon World Series in Mexico.
